To this day, it remains the largest wreck of a passenger ship (Costa Concordiaâ€™s partial sinking in 2012 doesnâ€™t count since it was moved and eventually scrapped). You probably guessed by now that I am a bit of a â€œbathtub admiralâ€ amongst many other interests. Indeed I find ships even more fascinating than trains or cars since Iâ€™m fully aware that the Earthâ€™s seas and oceans lie virtually unexplored. The wreck of His Majesty's Hospital Ship (HMHS) Britannic itself was only discovered by Jacques Cousteau in 1975, around 59 years after the sinking. Touring the Britannic in its digital format and witnessing its sinking simulation, were very enjoyable instances as they spared me of any unnecessary unpleasantries such as cheesy love stories in the vein of Cameronâ€™s Titanic from 1997. Three hours and a half runtime out of which about a quarter was dedicated to the actual sinking, of course. Britannic cuts right to the chase if you wish, while preserving plenty of surprises for those patient enough to explore the ship at a more relaxed pace. Developed and published by Vintage Digital Revival, a name which Iâ€™ve known for quite a few years since theyâ€™ve been working on â€œTitanic: Honor and Gloryâ€ since 2012. Glad to see that the experience gained from that on-going project could still materialize in a simulation for the ship which might have eclipsed the Titanic, if only the Patroness would have survived World War Oneâ€¦ Thereâ€™s an entire game section dedicated to both trivia and the actual history of the RMS / HMHS Britannic. You surely didnâ€™t expect a self-respecting interactive museum experience to force a few trips on Wikipedia now, did you? In fact Patroness of the Mediterranean received support from Simon Mills, the maritime historian and current owner of the wreck. You will find in-game, all the information you might desire about the Britannic while I shall provide below a YouTube clip involving the exploration of the ship in its current state, slowly decaying on the bottom of the Mediterranean. Itâ€™s important to notice that this is a considerably slower decay rate than the one on Titanic, given that the latterâ€™s resting at a depth of 12,600 feet (almost 4 kilometers), in the middle of the Atlantic where not even sunlight can reach it. In a fortunate twist of fate, Britannicâ€™s redesigning which was forced by Titanicâ€™s sinking, had managed to save almost all the passengers aboard the aptly named Patroness of the Mediterranean. Britannic sank twice as fast as her smaller sister-ship, in less than an hour yet the considerably larger number of lifeboats (way above the required carrying capacity) ensured that only 30 out of 1065 people lost their lives on the 21st of November 1916 when the hospital ship was traversing the Kea Channel as it sailed into a naval mine layed by the Imperial German Navy. I want to make this very clear, weâ€™re not talking of yet another disputed war crime as in the case of RMS Lusitania and its torpedoing by a German submarine in 1915. A tragedy nonetheless, yet one which the Britannic could not avoid.  Skip to 33:45. The damage done by the mine caused malfunctions in the shipâ€™s watertight doors which failed to close properly. An explosion canâ€™t be compared to scratching an iceberg and yet the circumstances surrounding the Olympic-class of ocean liners were so dire that two of its three representatives had violent, sudden demises. They cemented the idea of maritime disasters for passenger vessels and have undoubtedly remained examples or cautionary tales even a century away from those events. Likewise, this loss could not be redeemed by the post-WW1 restitution of a German ocean liner (SS Bismarck, renamed RMS Majestic) as part of war reparations.  Intriguing as its story may be, I was given a less-stellar impression upon noticing the performance issues exhibited by Patroness of the Mediterranean during my initial playthrough. Unreal Engine 4, an almost arch-nemesis to Unity Engine, has once again caused a mild nuisance in the form of crashes to desktop. UE4 is indeed powering this project, yet it took me some time to fiddle with both the in-game settings and my own GPU driver until I could enjoy it without CTDs albeit even worse performance from a frame rate perspective.  I had to â€œwind downâ€ the automatic overclock on my graphics card, rest assured that this isnâ€™t an isolated case and that rendering Britannic in its full visual glory will take a considerable toll on any high end system regardless of its age. Mine is four years old, so itâ€™s â€œancientâ€, I know. The Patroness wanted to teach me a lesson in humility, one which I could not accept until she was bent to my will, so I had found a compromise that would allow me to extract as many gorgeous screenshots as I wanted from her. The inherent lack of a HUD is something many more similar titles should implement. Surprisingly, thereâ€™s voice acting with quite a personality as well. Narrator Robinâ€™s thick accent (canâ€™t really pinpoint it though) is only matched by his innocuous jokes throughout the shipâ€™s tour. You can explore the shipâ€™s exterior as you wish, while the interior is slightly more limited at the time of this writing, with tooltips hinting at future expansion for the virtual museum. …‹éƒ½æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»ŽåŸå¢“é‡Œçˆ¬å‡ºæ¥çš„ï¼Œæ­»è€Œå¤ç”Ÿçš„å®¶ä¼™ï¼Œç”šè‡³åœ¨fibçœ¼ä¸­ï¼Œä»–æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰ç€æŠŠæŸ„çš„å‚€å„¡ã€‚æœ€è®©ä»–å¿ƒç—›çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œä»–ç‰ºç‰²ä¸€åˆ‡æ¢æ¥çš„å®¶äººå´å¹¶ä¸é¢†æƒ…ï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä»–ä¹‹åŽå¦‚åŒå¯¹å¾…å„¿å­ä¸€æ ·å¯¹å¾…å°å¯Œçš„åŽŸå› ï¼Œæ›´æ˜¯å½“å°å¯Œæ€ä»–ï¼Œéº¦å…‹å¿ƒç°æ„å†·çš„åŽŸå› ã€‚éº¦å…‹çš„æ­»åŒæ ·æ˜¯æ‚²å“€çš„ï¼Œä»–çš„ç”Ÿæ´»åˆšåˆšä»Žè¡Œå°¸èµ°è‚‰å˜å¾—æ‹¥æœ‰æ„ä¹‰ï¼Œä»–ç»ˆäºŽæŽ¥å›žäº†è‡ªå·±çš„å®¶äººï¼Œåšä¸Šäº†è‡ªå·±å–œæ¬¢çš„äº‹ä¸šï¼Œåˆšåˆšå¾—çŸ¥ç‰¹èŽ±è¥¿è€ƒä¸Šäº†å¤§å­¦ï¼Œå°±è¢«çœ¼å‰è‡ªå·±æœ€ä¿¡ä»»çš„äººèƒŒå›ã€‚è¢«é€¼ä¸Šç»è·¯æ—¶ï¼Œä»–çªç„¶æƒ³åˆ°ï¼Œä»–çš„å®¶åº­ä¾ç„¶è„†å¼±ï¼Œæ‰€è°“çš„äº‹ä¸šä¹Ÿä¸è¿‡å°±æ˜¯ç”¨å¤šå¹´å‰ä¸€æ ·çš„è‚®è„æ‰‹æ®µè¾¾æˆçš„äº¤æ˜“ï¼Œè‡ªå·±åŒå¤šå¹´å‰æ²¡æœ‰ä»»ä½•å˜åŒ–ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä»–æ‰’å¼€å°å¯Œçš„æ‰‹ï¼Œé€‰æ‹©ç»“æŸè‡ªå·±ç½ªå­½çš„ä¸€ç”Ÿã€‚ å´”ä½›æ˜¯æ¸¸æˆä¸­æœ€çŸ›ç›¾çš„ä¸€ä¸ªäººï¼Œå› æ­¤å¾ˆå¤šäººå¯¹ä»–çš„åå‘å…¶å®žæ˜¯å’Œéº¦å…‹çš„å¯¹æ¯”ä¸­äº§ç”Ÿçš„ã€‚æ­£å¦‚è¯ºé¡¿æ‰€è¯´ï¼Œå´”ä½›æ˜¯ä¸€é¢—ä¸å®šæ—¶ç‚¸å¼¹ï¼Œæ²¡äººçŸ¥é“ä»–ä»€ä¹ˆæ—¶å€™ä¼šæ…å¨„å­ã€‚ä»–çš„ç™»åœºæ˜¯è®©äººéœ‡æƒŠçš„ã€Œå› ä¸ºæœ¬äººåœ¨çŽ©vä¹‹å‰æ­£å¥½åœ¨çŽ©ivçš„dlcï¼Œå¼ºå°¼ä¸»è§’ã€ï¼Œçœ‹æ¥ræ˜Ÿä¸ºäº†å¡‘é€ è¿™ä¹ˆä¸€ä¸ªç–¯ç™«çš„è§’è‰²æ˜¯èŠ±äº†å¤§æ‰‹ç¬”çš„ã€‚å¾ˆå¤šäººè¯´è€å´”è®²ä¹‰æ°”ï¼Œå…¶å®žä»–åªæ˜¯çœŸæ€§æƒ…ï¼Œä»–çŸ¥é“ä»€ä¹ˆäººå€¼å¾—ä»–åŽ»çæƒœï¼Œè€Œä»€ä¹ˆäººéœ€è¦ç«‹åˆ»é™¤æŽ‰ï¼Œå“ªæ€•è¿™ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹è¡€è…¥è€Œåˆå¯æ€•ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚è¡¨å“¥ä¸€å®¶ã€‚è€å´”çš„å½¢è±¡æ— ç–‘æ˜¯æˆåŠŸçš„ï¼Œä»–å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ä¿®è¾¹å¹…çš„äººï¼Œå³ä½¿æ‹¥æœ‰è´¢å¯Œä¹Ÿä¸äº«å—è´¢å¯Œï¼Œå¯¹äºŽä»–æ¥è®²ï¼Œåˆºæ¿€æ‰æ˜¯å”¯ä¸€çš„åŠ¨åŠ›ã€‚ç›¸è¾ƒäºŽéº¦å…‹çš„æ‹¼å‘½åŒ…è£…ï¼Œå´”ä½›æ›´åƒæ˜¯è£¸å¥”ã€‚ä¹Ÿè®¸éº¦å…‹åŠªåŠ›å¾€è‡ªå·±è„¸ä¸Šè´´é‡‘çš„æ ·å­å¾ˆä¸‘é™‹ï¼Œä½†ä¸€ä¸ä¸æŒ‚å°±ç¾Žäº†ä¹ˆï¼Ÿå®Œå…¨æ²¡æœ‰ã€‚ä½†å´”ä½›çš„é—ªå…‰ä»ç„¶æ˜Žæ˜¾ï¼Œä»–å¯¹å…„å¼Ÿæœ‰ç€æ— æ¡ä»¶çš„æ”¯æŒï¼Œä»–ä¼šå› ä¸ºå¸ƒèŽ±å¾·çš„æ­»åŽæ‚”ç»ˆç”Ÿï¼Œä¼šåœ¨å°å¯Œè¯´éœ€è¦å¸®å¿™çš„æ—¶å€™éšå«éšåˆ°ï¼Œç„¶è€Œä»–å°±æ˜¯è¿™ä¹ˆä¸€ä¸ªæ´»åœ¨ç«¥è¯é‡Œçš„å•çº¯çš„äººï¼Œç¤¾ä¼šå½“ç„¶ä¸ä¼šç»™ä»–ç«¥è¯çš„ç»“å±€ã€‚å¾ˆå¤šäººç—›æ–¥éº¦å…‹ï¼Œæ‹’ç»é€‰æ‹©æ€æ­»è€å´”çš„ç»“å±€ï¼Œä½†è¯•æƒ³ï¼Œä½ å¸Œæœ›ä¸€ä¸ªè¿™æ ·çš„äººåšä½ çš„æœ‹å‹ï¼Ÿæ²¡é”™ï¼Œè€å´”å¾ˆçœŸè¯šï¼Œä½†ä½ ä¼šå¸Œæœ›è‡ªå·±çš„å…„å¼Ÿç»™ä½ ä¸€ç›˜çœ¼å±Žç»™ä½ åƒï¼Ÿä½ ä¼šå¸Œæœ›ä»–æ€äº†ä¸€å±‹å­äººç„¶åŽå’Œä½ ååœ¨ä»–ä»¬çš„å°¸ä½“ä¸Šå–é…’ï¼Ÿè€å´”ä¸èƒ½èžå…¥ç¤¾ä¼šï¼Œå› ä¸ºä»–æ ¹æœ¬ä¸æƒ³èžå…¥ç¤¾ä¼šã€‚ä»–åªæƒ³èžå…¥ä»–çš„å…„å¼Ÿï¼Œä½†ä»–çš„ä¸€åˆ‡åˆæ— æ³•è®©ä»»ä½•ä¸€ä¸ªäººæŽ¥å—ã€‚ çŽ°åœ¨ä½ æ˜¯å°å¯Œï¼Œä½ è¦é¢å¯¹è¿™ä¸ªé€‰æ‹©ï¼Œä½ æ˜¯æ€æŽ‰è™šä¼ªå¯æ¶çš„éº¦å…‹ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯ç–¯ç™«å±é™©çš„å´”ä½›ï¼Œæˆ–è€…å’Œè¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªæ··è›‹ä¸€èµ·å’Œæ•´ä¸ªä¸–ç•Œä½œå¯¹ï¼Ÿ æ€æŽ‰è€å´”ï¼Œè¢«ç§°ä¸ºæ˜Žæ™ºä¹‹ä¸¾ã€‚æˆ‘è¯´åˆ°åº•ï¼Œæ›´åƒéº¦å…‹è¿™æ ·çš„äººï¼Œæˆ‘å¸Œæœ›è‡ªå·±åšäº‹æœ‰åˆ†å¯¸ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›å®‰ç¨³å¯Œè¶³çš„ç”Ÿæ´»ã€‚å¯¹äºŽè€å´”ï¼Œæˆ‘æ²¡æœ‰å¯¹éº¦å…‹é‚£æ ·çš„æ•¬é‡ã€‚æˆ‘æ‰¿è®¤å´”ä½›çš„å®žåŠ›ï¼Œå´åˆå®³æ€•ä»–çš„å®žåŠ›ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™ä¸ªç–¯å­ç»å¸¸ä¸ºè‡ªå·±å¸¦æ¥éº»çƒ¦ï¼Œç”šè‡³æ­»äº¡ã€‚å‘½ä»¤è‡ªå·±æ€æŽ‰è€å´”çš„æ˜¯fibï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€å¸®ä¸éœ€è¦é™¤æŽ‰è‡ªå·±ï¼Œå´å¯ä»¥è®©è‡ªå·±æ··ä¸ä¸‹åŽ»çš„äººã€‚æˆ‘å¥½ä¸å®¹æ˜“æ¢æ¥çš„ç”Ÿæ´»ï¼Œè¦ä¸ºäº†ä»–è€Œæ¯æŽ‰ï¼Ÿæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘æ€äº†ä»–ï¼Œé™¤äº†åŽæ‚£ã€‚è‡³äºŽéº¦å…‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸ç”¨æ‹…å¿ƒä»–çš„èƒŒå›ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä»–ä¸æ˜¯å–œæ¬¢èƒŒå›ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸æ˜¯ä»–çš„å¨èƒï¼Œç”šè‡³æ˜¯ä»–çš„åŠä¸ªå„¿å­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä¸€èµ·é™¤äº†å´”ä½›ï¼Œåœ¨ä¸€èµ·æžå®šé‚£ä¸ªå«æˆ‘ä»¬å·è½¦çš„æ··è›‹ï¼Œè¿™å®žåœ¨æ˜¯æ˜Žæ™ºä¹‹ä¸¾ï¼Œæˆ‘ç”šè‡³æŽ¥ä¸‹æ¥çš„å‡ åå¹´éƒ½ä¸ç”¨çŠ¯æ„ã€‚ {"text": "Being the latest installment of the GTA franchise (as of 2017), GTA V (or 5) is not all that bad. Although I don't play the game that much anymore, when I bought the game on it's PC launch on steam back in 2015, I was pretty hyped and decided to write a review. Looking back now, GTA V had a pretty interesting storyline for it's Singleplayer Campaign. The first of the franchise to have the ability to switch between 3 different characters (in Singleplayer). It's multiplayer however, is a bit of a let down. You can spend either 24 hours grinding for a certain amount of in game money, or buy that amount of money with real money in just a few clicks. For most players, the latter is disappointing. You have people that have played the game for a long time, only to find out that they've been trumped by another player with a quarter of the playtime and experience just because the other player was willing to spend extra money. The online heists were quite a thrill when they came out, but then they started adding all these freemode events and \"extra-curricular\" CEO type missions. It just put online mode into more of a grind than before.  However, I will give credit to it's Singleplayer design. That's all I really have to say at this point.", "appid": "271590", "steamid": "profiles/76561198107465586", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "7", "votes_funny": "4", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1431259200.0}

{"text": "In my opinion, Nioh is probably the best Samurai hack and slash game out there currently. It takes all the good things in the likes of Dynasty and samurai warriors (rich history and story background of feudal Japanese shogunate war) while merging it with the souls-like system (the soul recovery, revenant , and stamina based combat). In addition to that, this game also has a ton of extra missions that you can spend on if youhave already completed the main game which actually would take a decent amount of time. You can also strive for 100% completion of extra things like the Kodama or legendary weapons farming.  However, this game does also come with a few flaws which are the amount of unnecessary system that has been added to it as if the game itself already doesn't have enough of them. The whole prestige system and hidden teahouse and all that is kinda unimportant and for the most part cna be ignored. The loot drop system is also kinda overdone that may make somew newcomers feel uninterested. The main storyline of this game is also quite simplistic and not very immersive in a way. But all in all, the game overcame it's flaws with the 10/10 combat and great level design as well as boos fight. {"text": "When Beyond the wire was first announcedI was skeptical whether there would be Btw's \"own place\" in current gaming market where we already have WW1 multiplayer games like Battlefield 1 and Verdun but I'm happy to say there is. Instead of being in completely open dead-zones like in Verdun or BF1 were you have special-soldiers Btw is a very carefully set between of these games. The maps present in the early access are forest areas with trenches and that works the best for the game. Most of the time you have trenches were the flag points are but between those you have forest areas were you can get more tactical on your movement. It feels perfect when you are crawling to next objective area and hear bolt action rifles shooting rounds left and right of you but you are not sure was it friendly or enemy. The melee system advertised in the shop description works well too. However, the game is clearly an early access product and there's not a whole lot of tutorials/ explaining done. For example, I had no idea what determines the win when there are no in-game timers except for each capture zone. Or do we have whole side ticket amount that is hidden from all players? I don't know how squad leaders set up rally points or static weapons/ covers. Is there a way see if I already reloaded my rifle before I got wounded by the enemy? etc. Beyond the wire is a promising early access ww1 mp game that still needs more servers and tutorials in order to aid players understand better the game. {"text": ", the game mechanics feel right and you actually enjoy playing. Story feels rushed and frustrating but western drama mixed with demons and devils saves the day. The whole story is divied into 8 scenerios. Some of them are sequels of the previous one or some provide a different timeline and perspective thus expanding the universe and providing extra insight about things going on. So in general eight interconnected or directly connected scenarios provide an overall absorbing experience. However all these tales make the story extremely frustrating to understand and follow. You can't catch up with the game, you can't fill the gaps between the scenarious and etc. Note that because of the distinctive language, it is truly hard to understand some of text or at least word for word. Game consists of two types of gameplay.   is about travelling on the map, deciding choices, getting equipment and consumables, making some side quests to get extra stuff or more importantly gaining advantages or disadvantages for actual turn based gameplay. With every scenario or at least for most of the scenarios, you get new mechanics to play this mode. Thats a good freshment since your equipment, stuff and squad reset with each scenario and you have to start over.  is why we are here for, turn based combat. Well gameplay is mostly satisfying but lacks some crucial skills like overwatch. However, there are tons of skills and you get these with equipments or card system. Card system provides stat bonusses and skills to your characters. If you make a good hand with these cards, you get extra bonusses such as getting +3 HP for a royal flush. You get these cards by travelling on the map and doing side or main objectives. One thing to mention is luck system which adds another layer of strategy, deepining the gameplay. It is a very simple thing but truly making the game better. I wish XCOM had something like that. Loot system is meh. There isn't any huge difference between guns except few. Consumables are diverse and useful but you don't need to use them all since simply moving and shooting is a better option.   are satisfying (shooting) and soundtrack has the modernized western touch which i have enjoyed quite much.  is similar to scenarios even better but, when you actually start enjoying and then it's over...", "appid": "307670", "steamid": "profiles/76561198216542593", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1568289600.0}

{"text": "The witching hour is near, for the wind is howling while an indigo sky looms over the horizon. The familiar becomes strange at midnight for your protagonist in  . Ghosts, glitches, and other strange happenings move the events of this game, where you play a college girl who has to work a midnight shift at her local convenience store. It would be a mistake to settle in the mundanity of her wotk, because it is precisely in the nornalcy of her job that a sinister madness is brewing, waiting to unleash its curse. One strength of   is aesthetic consistency. The Convenience Store | å¤œå‹¤äº‹ä»¶ (much like Stigmatized Property | äº‹æ•…ç‰©ä»¶, Inunaki Tunnel | çŠ¬é³´ãƒˆãƒ³ãƒãƒ«, and Aka Manto | èµ¤ãƒžãƒ³ãƒˆ) delivers a steady flow of Japanese retro aesthetic horror. The mechanical whirs of a VHS tape machine pulling the tape out from the cassette shell and wrapping it around the inclined head drum are embodied in the art style of this game: saturated colors and brightness, low resolution, VHS tape noise, interlacing, static, and jitter in the analog video signal. It feels as if we're watching somebody else's home videos.  The Convenience Store | å¤œå‹¤äº‹ä»¶ codes its aesthetics to localized Japanese urban legends and myths. This creates an alienating yet intimate sense of place for the player to explore. It is alienating because it is foreign. You live near a ghost town, its always night, the only place that is open is the convenient store you work at, which is very bright, and almost everyone that comes in seems just a bit off-kilter. What are these VHS tapes I keep recieving...? Was that a glitch in the CCTVs or was it just your peripherals? In addition, this sense of place is also intimate because it accounts for a highly personalized, qualitative, and \"inside-look\" into the life and happenings of this college girl.  has a reputation of delivering haunting experiences to a backdrop of paranormal realism. Unlike in other entries, The Convenience Store | å¤œå‹¤äº‹ä»¶ opts out of a found footage format for a more introspective perspective that effectively puts the player in the protagonist's shoes. Through the use of a seemingly repetitive storyline (namely playing the \"same midnight shift\" three to four times to progress) the player becomes accustomed to the mundanity of work: clocking in, dealing with your annoying co-worker, replenishing the shelves, taking out the trash, etc. However, it is in the differentiated details from each shift our protagonist plays, it is in the blinks of our eyes, in the shadows of our periphery, that evil spirits await to be awakened.", "appid": "1228520", "steamid": "profiles/76561198024812228", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "24", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1591012800.0}

{"text": "If you are looking for the Grand Strategy Space Empire game, you need not look much further then Stellaris, it covers most of the desires you could have, a modest customization option where you can create your empire as you may want it to start, the game has a learning curve that is not to dangerous and you will pick up most things relativly fast. {"text": "What would happen if the heroes of the story lose the final battle to save the world? what would people think about them? that's the premise of this story, with a little twist. Instead of controlling the heroes the main characters will be what you would call the \"extras\" in any other game. They will help the heroes return to their home to see the end of the world with their family and friends. The game is divided into 8 chapters (although 3 of them are only cutscenes) and you will control 1 different character on each one. And like i said you will not control the heroes, but you can summon them on combat to help you with different skills. On every chapter you will find a mix of exploration, combat, side quests and some puzzles (some of them are really tricky). Combat wise you will need to master the \"call\" function, knowing when to summon the heroes and for what. And at the end of each chapter you will get points depending on how you finished it, that will reward you with some perks to help you along the way. I found the art really nice and like every game from RosePortal music is really good, specially the songs used in combat. So in the end i can say that the game is really fun (also a little hard sometimes), and although the game is not long completing ranks, side quests and getting all achievements will take you a while.  If you like RPG Maker games give it a try, for that price i don't think you're gonna lose much.", "appid": "421810", "steamid": "profiles/76561197983608283", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "15", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1449921600.0}

{"text": "Warframe is the best F2P game I've ever played.  Most of the items can be earned simply from playing the game.  Like most F2P games they do limit your inventory space, but you can earn platinum from trading with other players.  This premium currency can be used to buy more inventory space, cosmetics, items or time saving boosters.  Overall it feels like a fair system.   The actual gameplay is very fluid and you really do feel like an invincible space ninja.  There are 37 different warframes to collect and master.  Each with their own unique skills and play styles.  There are also hundreds of weapons and mods that you can combine in different ways to support your play style.  Warframe has a surprising amount of depth and you will still be learning new things after spending hundreds of hours in the game.  The game is primarily co-op PVE, but there is also a PVP mode.   The Developers continue to push new content out for the game and listen to player feedback on any changes they make.  They seem to respect their customers and want to make Warframe the best game it can be.  The community is also very helpful and friendly to new players.", "appid": "230410", "steamid": "profiles/76561197978011539", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "2", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1542888000.0}

{"text": "genre : point and click adventure game with HOG elements score : 9/10  You play as an investigator of the occult and supernatural, trying to solve the mystery of the disappearance of your sister in the city of San Francisco. Mystery involves paranormal happenings and the unnatural but in a realistic and believable way. + The presentation is the best i have seen in a casual adventure game, dynamic with sublime artwork. + Sound and voice-overs are excellent. + Story is interesting, dark and although it includes things of the supernatural the presentation is in a realistic way. I'm sure the developers have played gabriel knight before. + Gameplay is really fresh, it's almost entirely point and click gameplay as in classic adventure games with the HOG scenes being implemented as part of the story, which is fine by me - some action scenes where you have to use your revolver - scenes where you have to use your detective sense - other times you use a watch which helps reconstrust the past. All gameplay elements are explained well and they suit the progression of the story. - Short in duration, but this is the 1st episode of 4 in total. The full season and for the asking price probably will be worth it as far as game length is concerned. - Pretty easy, maybe this first episode acts as an introduction to the season, sometimes it feels like a tutorial.  Bought this game during the halloween sale and i was pretty amazed by the production values. It seems Artifex Mundi have found a big opponent in the casual adventure games genre, or vice versa since i think this product quality wise is a big step forward for the genre. Will definitely buy the season pack and i am keeping my eye on these developers for other games in the future.", "appid": "483420", "steamid": "profiles/76561198006697906", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "12", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1478174400.0}

{"text": "Grand Theft Auto V has stood the test of time. Being the most recent of a series of games in the GTA series, GTA V has improvements over the past games, and includes more than just a story mode. Although the story mode can keep you entertained for months on end, trying to collect everything and beat the game with a perfect score, if you like playing with others, you can try Online. Although online has its problems with cheaters, overpriced cars, and such, it is still amazing to play with friends and meet some on GTA Online. {"text": "If you're looking for a game review you've come to the wrong place. But if youre looking for a fantastic ravioli recipe you've come to the right place. Ingredients - To Make the Dough 375 grams (3 cups) plain flour 1/2 teaspoon salt 2 eggs 1/4 cup (50 ml / 3Â½ tablespoons) olive oil 1/2 cup (120 ml / 8 tablespoons) water Extra flour for dusting  - To Make Cheese Filling 15 ounces (425 grams) container Ricotta cheese 5 ounces (142 g/about 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons) \"3 Cheese Italian Blend\" (Parmesan, Romano & Asiago) Note: grate these cheeses yourself and create your own custom blend. 1/2 cup cheddar cheese 2 eggs, lightly beaten 1/2 teaspoon salt 1/2 teaspoon pepper - Extras Your favorite sauce for the ravioli (i.e. marinara/ marijuana) Parmesan cheese Basil Fried vegetables Shrimp Fish slices Chicken pieces  cinnamon (a reviewer said it's legit) Make the Ravioli filling. - In a small mixing bowl, add the ricotta and mash with a fork. - Add in the 3-cheese blend, Cheddar cheese, eggs, salt, and pepper. - Mix all ingredients thoroughly until you have a smooth, paste-like consistency. - Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes.  Make the Ravioli dough. - Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix. - Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed. - Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough. - Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic. - Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters. - With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles). - Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Dough can keep for weeks when frozen. Just make sure to wrap well so that it doesnâ€™t suffer from freezer burn or absorb freezer odor.  Fill the Ravioli shells. - Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough. - Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle. - Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a â€œhomemadeâ€ touch as well. - Repeat this process for all your dough circles. - Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together.  Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker. - Roll the dough into two sheets - Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups. - Fill with the ravioli mixture. - Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling. - Remove and separate the finished raviolis. Cook the Ravioli. - Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil. - Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test. - If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest  - Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed plates Serve it up. Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy!", "appid": "202970", "steamid": "profiles/76561198088235800", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "271", "votes_funny": "357", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1491048000.0}

{"text": "Battalion 1944 finally released like a phoenix out of its early access ashes. If you're familiar to the more 00s or 90s first person shooters and desire to play something as fast paced as that, you'll be in for a treat. B44 is a competitive game where practice makes perfect. You can play it casually in its limited time mode or arcade where you'll hone your gunplay and movement. These modes tend to have respawn, so it's fun to just dive in, shoot and learn the maps. On the other hand you can dive into Wartide with a more serious and competitive vibe and you'll be trying to spend your time as effective as possible. Because if you die, you'll have to sit out the round and hope your teammates will do well. Whether you'll win or lose, the matches are all intergrated with Faceit, so it has a sense of legitimacy in there right from the start. The guns sound great from the satisfying ping of a M1 garand to the loud blasts of your snipers. If you have a keen sense of hearing, you'll be able to track and anticipate your enemies well based on their sounds. The graphics can be tweaked to your likings. I really enjoy the amount of customization in here and you can make it as fancy as you want or as ..uhh visibility-focused as you prefer. ;D Their modding tools are also fun and easy to use. (if you follow the tutorial videos on their channel and know a bit of UE4.)  I can't wait to see what others will be creating and there are already quite some ambitious and interesting mods or maps to follow. Overall, I always felt Battalion 1944 had potential during the Early Access phase, but just needed the care and polish it deserved. Thankfully I can truly say they succeeded and if you're into fast paced competitive shooters, you should definitely add this one to your library.", "appid": "489940", "steamid": "profiles/76561197993738236", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "5", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1559131200.0}

{"text": "Very fun game if you like tanks.  It isn't as detailed as car mechanic simulator when it comes to the engine but the rest of the tank can take a while to prep and fix.  Most of the time you are de-rusting, sanding, priming and painting parts.  It isn't a very complicated game but for some reason it's fun.  I can just sit and relax and fix up tanks.  Excavation of tanks is really cool too.  You never know what you are going to find out there.  The upgrades to your shop and skills are nice.  The music is pretty lame so I just turn the radio off while I play.  It would be cool if they added different radio stations to listen to while you fix stuff. {"text": "Resident Evil 7 is a slow-paced, story-driven, survival-horror FPS game released in early 2017. Heralded as a soft-reboot for the franchise, RE7 appears a perfect starting point to jump into the series. Iâ€™ve never personally played a game in the Resident Evil franchise before, so RE7 was a pleasant surprise for me. The game is about as elegant and well designed as a horror title can get, with only a few missteps. Iâ€™ll say now that if youâ€™re a fan of the genre, Resident Evil 7 is a must play. In Resident Evil 7 you enter the life of Ethan Winters, an undeveloped protagonist outside of the fact that his wife, Mia, has been missing for three years. She disappeared on a mysterious job she was working, but then at the start of RE7 contacts Ethan, telling him to come to Dulvey, Louisiana to find her at the Baker Family Ranch. Suspicious but overjoyed to discover that his wife is alive, Ethan makes for Louisiana and enters the swamplands of the Baker estate. What he finds there beggars belief. One of the most important elements of any horror experience is the presentation. Luckily, Resident Evil 7 delivers beautifully on this front. The art style is uncut realism, featuring extremely lifelike environments, models, and effects. Textures, atmosphere, and post processing are all of A-grade quality for 2017, and hold up perfectly well three years on. The lighting and faces are particularly impressive though. RE7â€™s lighting is dynamic, moody, and claustrophobically dark, while the realism of the faces can produce grotesque spectacles. The only visual defect can be found in the somewhat janky movement animations. As for the sound, I have no complaints. Audio is consistently good, with terrifying ambiance and a fitting OST. Performance is also damn-near perfection, with hardly any bugs and comprehensive PC optimization. When it comes to presentation, RE7 has no true shortcomings. The level design in RE7 is an aspect that is part presentation, part gameplay. The decrepit Baker Family Ranch is eerie and hideous, contributing to the atmospheric unease. Various environmental details tell the story of what has occurred there, but Iâ€™ll leave that for you to discover. From a gameplay perspective, the level design is broadly â€œlinear,â€ but this is not entirely the case. You can return to almost all of the areas youâ€™ve been to previously, however as you make progress throughout the campaign there is usually only one way of doing things. Due to the linearity and this being a game that thrives on the playerâ€™s fear, some moments are distressing when the single path forward is unclear and you become trapped by enemies. Whether this is a failing or an intentional feature of the design, Iâ€™ll leave up to you. Looking at what you actually do in the game, itâ€™s a mix of classical survival-horror and FPS mechanics. Your movement speed is painfully slow, so running away from danger is usually a poor option â€“ youâ€™re meant to sneak around or stand your ground. When it comes to standing your ground, there are various weapons and tools youâ€™ll collect throughout the game. The guns vary wildly in effectiveness; for instance, the pistol is basically a water gun, and the shotgun functions like youâ€™re shooting a damn freight train. RE7 also has the same obligatory loot and crafting system of all survival-horror games these days, enabling you to create first aid meds, pistol bullets, etc. The fun side of this crafting system is that resources are actually extremely limited. Every encounter with an enemy will cost you, making the non-boss fights feel like mini wars of attrition. And when it comes to the bosses, each battle is simultaneously frightening and challenging, keeping you engaged in frantic attempts to destroy your adversary as you pour more and more resources into combat. This core gameplay loop is so surprisingly good, but whatâ€™s better is that itâ€™s only the second best item on the menu of what RE7 is serving. At Resident Evil 7â€™s opening, the game is absolutely terrorizing. Like, muscles-tensed-up-and-fight-or-flight-reflexes-engaged-in-real-life kind of terrorizing. This level of intensity fades after about 2 hours, but the sensation of angst and anxiety as you approach every corner never fades entirely during the 8-10 hour campaign. I believe the sickening setting of the Baker estate, the possessed inhabitants themselves, the resiliency of the enemies, the graphics, the audio, and the uncertainty of what the hell is going on in the narrative all have a hand in producing the most palpably â€œhorror-ificâ€ atmosphere of any game Iâ€™ve ever played. RE7 has the classical horror theme down to an absolute science. Ending on a bit of an anticlimax, the story itself is a bit of an anticlimax. This isnâ€™t to say the writing is particularly bad, but for a game that spends a decent amount of time emphasizing its story, there really should have been more here. The main narrative beat is about what has possessed the Baker Family that is holding your wife Mia captive, and figuring out why they are functionally immortal. You accomplish this through encounters with each family member individually, as each member of the Baker Family has a stage of the game where they are the primary antagonist. This is an interesting enough mystery to solve, but the reasons behind their possession are never explained too well, and none of the characters in RE7 are compelling or relatable. In essence, the writing is very bare bones. The splendid gameplay and great atmosphere certainly make up for this one deficiency, but it holds Resident Evil 7 back from the dizzying heights it was so close to. Resident Evil 7 is a refreshingly clear cut, good game in a genre full of mediocrity. It executes on its core design principles flawlessly, resulting in an experience that should be regarded as a shining example of how to do horror right. Its level of polish is something Iâ€™ve only hinted at so far, but I believe itâ€™s what makes RE7 as outstanding as it is. Other than the underdeveloped story, there is absolutely nothing about the game that I can point to as a big shortcoming. Add in the high points of its frenetic boss battles and the crippling anxiety its scary side produces, and you have an instant classic on your hands. If you have any level of interest in playing Resident Evil 7, do not hesitate. *Note: RE7 has one short free DLC, â€œNot a Hero,â€ which I have played. It introduces a few new gameplay mechanics and expands upon the story in the aftermath of the main game. Itâ€™s a solid addition if you enjoyed RE7, however itâ€™s less survival-horror and a lot more FPS-horror.", "appid": "418370", "steamid": "profiles/76561198257905891", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "80", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1578225600.0}

{"text": "Very interesting little game. It got a considerable amount of press when it was just launched, and deservedly so, as being an oddity in the market. An RPG Maker title without real RPG elements, without a usable inventory, without quests, without fighting mechanics (no, THAT part does definitely not count), and completely story-driven... no wonder many have erroneously tried to argue that \"it's not a game\". {"text": "Dear Esther is the remake of an experimental mod for Half-Life 2. The original was developed by a research project at the University of Portsmouth led by professor and media researcher Dan Pinchbeck. The first thing that is to say about Dear Esther is: It's not a game. It has no gameplay elements and its experimental approach makes it impossible to categorize. The author calls it a \"ghost story, told using first-person gaming technologies\" but I'm not sure there is a ghost. I'm not even sure there is a story. If I had to put a label on it I would call it an attempt to evoke emotions with a series of randomised snippets of poetry that roughly ape a narrative structure, presented in the form of software. Not interactive poetry because it doesn't allow interaction. You are confined to the role of an observer, you can listen and watch but that's it. No puzzles, no dialogues, no characters, nothing can be touched, you can't even run or jump. With the words \"Dear Esther, ...\" the unnamed narrator begins his monologue and you, the unnamed protagonist, begin your walk across an unnamed and uninhabited island. And walking (slowly, painfully slowly) is all you will be doing for the next 1-2 hours if you want to \"play\" through the whole thing... walking and listening to the narrator who will occasionally be throwing in snippets of letters and diary entries. While you're following the strictly linear path (you will encounter invisible barriers all the time) you will notice strange symbols carved into rocks, some mysterious drawings, some chemical formulas, even ultrasound pictures of a baby. Maybe they're intended as clues to help decipher some kind of cryptic story, maybe they mean nothing at all. The scenery is very well designed, the music unobtrusive but beautiful. For me, the narrative does nothing. I find it pretentious, flowery with no substance or meaning. My predominant feeling when I was \"playing\" Dear Esther was that of boredom. But that's just me. If you are curious about this storytelling-experiment, by all means, try it out for yourself. If you will enjoy the experience or not is purely a matter of personal taste.", "appid": "203810", "steamid": "profiles/76561198056290009", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "204", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1386763200.0}

{"text": "These developers obv dont play pc games      To begin with, the game is still buggy as hell, and the mechanics have many flaws. Walking around just feels weird. I cant even tell you how many times my car has been destroyed by zombies bashing on my doors.      When they are on my car bashing, i tend to quietly kill them by pressing \"e\", but guess what, \"e\" has plenty of binds to it, so instead i hop into my car and it takes too long to get back out, and then you repeat the process until you just melee it and your car is engulfed in flames.      Its a shame because I truly enjoy this game, but for being a game that is almost two years old with the same issues from launch is unacceptable. Now with the multiplayer,       while it is multiplayer, you must use the \"xbox app\" to play with friends, which was most likely done to expand the player-base, and makes sense because im sure not many ppl will play this on steam, and if you look at the achievements, they are rarely completed, which makes me think those ppl either returned the game or are stuck with it because they put 3 hours of playtime.      I wish they did something different with the multiplayer as well, what i was hoping was that you and your friends are the community and you guys can survive together in this zombie world, and can recruit members along your journey, but instead it's just your friend helping your community, which is fine, but sort of boring and adds nothing to the story.      I didnt even cover everything about whats wrong with the game, and there are things that they implemented well. however they can be outweighed easily by all the issues this game still has. Other issues i've experienced is frequent crashing/freezing, the audio being insanely loud at launch and the gun sounds are also extremely high pitch, the radio chatter is too quiet, and what I hate the most is the amount of noise your camp makes even thought everyone is quiet and no machines are running, as if you couldn't tell your community to keep it down a notch. If you don't mind the bugs and have the $30 plus tax, then i'd say go for it and give it a try, otherwise i'd say steer clear from this title, as it lacks certain content, such as being a multiplayer game, when it really is a single-player game with added multiplayer elements.", "appid": "495420", "steamid": "profiles/76561198097880281", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "2", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1584532800.0}

{"text": "This game is the epitome of my depression. Let's have a flashback. Mid day. April 2020. I sit in my home, bored and staring at the wall. Many great games have come out recently, but I'm looking for more. I'm looking for a game I can pour ALL of my time in to. One of those games, like TF2 or CS:GO. I decide to look online and do some research, and I stumble across this forbidden apple tree. After loading it up, I was horrified. The stair section at the beginning of the game is an extreme parkour challenge designed for only the most able parkour masters, so as you'd expect I struggled for a little over 30 minutes. After I conquered the stairs, we had to go around in the hub world. And it was AWFUL. For 3 HOURS that I could have spent eating pretzel sticks in my bathtub, I played THIS. The game creators thought it would be a funny little joke to  make it impossible for people who are completely blind to participate in the game, so this part was exceptionally hard for me. But at long last, I had conquered my greatest challenge. I had beaten the game welcome to heaven. But then, I realized that you could banish people to hell. This game is a complete quirk, but don't get me wrong. If YOU have 3-4 hours to spare as well, play it! But if you value time, don't! This game is harder than Dark Souls. (Sorry if this review is bias I received the product for free.) This allows them to bypass overwatch as they hide their cheats quite well and make their shots look as if it was all luck. The situation is actually disgusting, where we now have people who queue with cheaters in order to gain a high rank, because at this point if you want to reach and maintain GE you either queue with cheaters or become one. And I forgot to mention that this is in Prime matchmaking, which is supposed to be fairly safe. These cheaters also have groups where they admit to cheating, even inviting more people to join them and play matchmaking while they either boost them or cheat together. CS:GO as a game is great, but I really hope Valve puts a hold on adding new skins all the time and actually makes a decent anti-cheat which bans all those external software users. I'm just a normal player who enjoys the game, I'm not looking to go big in CS, so I do not see why someone like myself would need to pay to play a legit game of ranked CS:GO. {"text": "This is IMO the best program in the world, I've used it for around 16 years so I hate to write a negative review for this amazing piece of software but sadly the Steam version is practically unusable for some people (me included).  The problem is that the games you create run at a very low framerate in fullscreen mode. In windowed mode you get a perfect 60FPS, however in fullscreen you get around 15, which is unplayable. The worst part is that you can't change the windowed resolution, so you're either stuck with a tiny window or unplayable performance.  Not everyone seems to suffer from that problem though, but it's not a gamble I'd partake in because you have to remember that you're creating games for other people to play, so your game might run normally for 60% of people and the other 40% run it at 15FPS.  Even worse, the original Japanese version (and Don Miguel's fan translation) runs without a problem. So basically people who use the pirated version (or who bought the original version in Japan) don't have this problem, only people who've bought this new release here on Steam. The problem has been known for OVER TWO YEARS and it's still not fixed, so I think it's safe to say that it will never be fixed. I've also tried all the other RPG Makers on Steam (besides MV) and they all seem to run flawlessly, so only RM2K has this problem.", "appid": "383730", "steamid": "profiles/76561197989764483", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "55", "votes_funny": "3", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1508414400.0}

{"text": "I hate to admit it but this is the first game I've encountered that has actually left me disappointed to the point that I would fail to recommend it, which sucks because I really want to like this game more. Being that it's still in Early Access I am hopeful that some of the issues will be addressed and I can change this to a positive review in the future, so take this with a grain of salt. First of all, one of the things that had originally caught my eye about this game was the promise of a \"Choose your own Nightmare\" and that the game was \"Open for you to explore\" as stated in its description... However, that could not be more far off from what this game really is. The game is completely linear, you don't have much of a choice on where to go or when you can go there. Technically speaking there are different stories for you to discover, but I wouldn't consider them as separate unique walk-throughs, they're more like different segments of a single walk-through. Each segment is pretty straight-forward and there's not a lot you can do or choices you can make that stray from what the developers want you do do, and to make matters worse the way this game hold your hand made me feel like it was meant for children.  Many times I hadn't even finished fully exploring a room (which I was forced to go into) when the item I was supposed to find was highlighted in a bright fluorescent outline. The Narrator does a very good job of telling you what to do even before you know you're supposed to do it, in fact, you could have just entered a room and he's already telling you where to go next and what to look for. And since we're on the topic of the Narrator, to even be able to hear him out you have to stand completely still, because if you move too much or pick up an item then the audio will cut out and the next audio segment will start automatically, making you miss out on some of the dialogue and forcing you go back and do it all over again just to make sure you didn't miss something important from the story. As for the story, it was decent at most but in my personal opinion it lacked more depth. Once I finished the game and reached the big reveal, which took only about 2 hours, I found myself thinking back on what I had just played through and asked myself how it all tied together, and for the life of me I just could not find an answer. Don't get me wrong, the game had its moments and there where some interesting plot twists along the way, but I just feel that as a whole they left me with more questions then answers. Now that we've gotten all of that out of the way, there are some redeeming qualities to this game as well. As a horror game it does a great job of setting up a grim mood for you to play through. The tone of the music is appropriate and graphically I don't have anything to complain about. I'll admit that this game got some great jump scares out of me and each individual story is completely different from the one before, but at the end of the day it just left me feeling like there was more that could have been done.  All in all though I think the bad far outweigh the good, at least in the games current state. The price tag is not bad but there are much cheaper games out there that have given me far more hours of entertainment than what I got from House on the Hill. If you wish to experience the game for yourself by all means go ahead, it's not a bad game, but as for my recommendation I would say to wait for the final release.", "appid": "1239050", "steamid": "profiles/76561198989559732", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "49", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1602849600.0}

{"text": "As much as I like the zombies mode, I would have to say that this game really isn't worth the $60 they're asking for it and the season pass isn't worth it either.            I could talk about how good the campaign is, but lets be perfectly honest here. Most people are buying Call of Duty games for the multiplayer and this one does not feel good at all. After coming from Black Ops 3 where the movement system, while not the most favorable, was extremely fluent and easy to use Infinite Warfare feels slow and sluggish. The movement system honestly feels like a cheap rip off. It feels extremely slow and clunky and is just not at all fun to play with.     Zombies is a fun game mode in this game. It reminds me alot of how Call of Duty:World at War was in terms of how meleeing works and what happens if the player gets too close to them. The perks and the pack-a-punch are all pretty much the same as Treyarch's but I am not going to fault them for that because of the old saying,\"If it ain't broke don't fix it.\" That's not to say that they haven't tweeked certain perks to make them a little bit better. An example would be how Stamin-Up's counter part Rancin' Stripes does what Stamin-Up did but also acts as the Gung-Ho perk allow players to throw grenade, pick up items and shoot while sprinting. The power-ups are also the same as Treyarch how ever they have added in special backpacks that drop various items such as different grenade types. Everything has it's place and once you get use to everything the game mode really starts to become fun.      I saved the supply drops for last because unlike previous games it doesn't just impact the multiplayer side anymore. The biggest positive is free guns when they get added. In multiplayer you complete a special challenge and in zombies you simply pick it up. The supply drops biggest flaw is the fact that if a player has the ability to spend real money they will simply be able to progress through the prototype lab at a much faster rate than those who can't, which gives them an unfair edge in multiplayer. On the other side of this \"coin\" is the fact that zombies is a co-op game where players work together to achieve a goal whether it be high rounds or to complete the easter egg on any of the maps. If a player has damage increasing epic weapon then in the long run it helps the entire team because that player will be able to kill more zombies and take a bit of pressure off of their team mates.     At the end of the day what helps to kill the game is the multiplayer which doesn't feel right and the lack of replayability across the board. The only reason to buy is if you are a player like me who is a hardcore zombies person because chances are you will actually enjoy it.", "appid": "292730", "steamid": "profiles/76561198165380919", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "3", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1495195200.0}

{"text": "First off, I was intially supportive of Hi-Rez, I was willing to look past the blantant knockoffs and kind of excited to play it. Pros: -Fast gameplay, easy to get into -Most of the champions are fairly interesting to play -Abilities are kinda cool, and it seems to be trying to mix a MOBA and a FPS together, which I can appreciate Cons: -The character designs are beyond uninspired (I'm going to dedicate some space to the art direction) The characters feel incredibly generic, and some seem very close to knocking off other characters. Grover, a support is literally the tree creature that Sylvanus rides in SMITE, except given an axe to throw, and the Roman god has probably hopped off of his back in shame. Grover functions very similarly to his SMITE counterpart, and some of his card art for his abilities is directly ripped from SMITE(which by the way, is not the only champion with card art ripped from SMITE, I hope is a clever nod to another Hi-Rez game, and not laziness, but who knows). Androxxus looks like Reaper from Overwatch, but with a couple changes to his color palette, and horns. The art for the maps is also incredibly lame, and makes me think of World of Warcraft, but with much less detail. -Maps are incredibly basic, and look very lame, with little variation in gameplay -Champions are mainly ripped from Overwatch and mashed together, for example Androxxus, which has a Primary that functions like Mccree's revolver, can unload half of the clip at a time with an alt-fire, reflects damage back at his enemies like Gengi(although I admit that it works a bit differently, so this isn't completely terrible), and has an odd dash similar to Gengi's swift strike in Overwatch. Makoa, which â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ nearly exactly like Overwatch's Roadhog, nearly at a a point where it looks like Roadhog was retextured. {"text": "STRAFE is a game with a severe identity crisis, as it pretends to be a fast paced oldschool style FPS, and that is certainly the feeling you get from all the traillers and adverts, but in fact its just a quirky roguelike fps, with an oldschool graphics style slapped on just for â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and giggles i guess.  It is so odd, the game portrays itself as being from 1996 in some of its promotional material, presumably as a callback to games from that era, but STRAFE really doesnt have anything in common with the games of that era, it lacks the flow, the level design, the interesting enemy behaviour and more stuff that made games like Duke Nukem 3D and Quake as special as they were. So if you are looking for a good throwback FPS, with memorable levels and fast gameplay, just go ahead and buy DUSK. However the question remains, is STRAFE itself worth it? At this point I'd love if steam had a midway point between Yes and No, because if you bypass the concept of what STRAFE looks like it should be, and just take it as an interesting departure from other roguelikes, then sure you can have a fair amount of fun with the game as I did. {"text": "Terrariaâ€™s final major update, Journeyâ€™s End (1.4), is here. And itâ€™s great! Iâ€™ll explain to all of you why I recommend Terraria. You should get this game right now since this update dropped. Iâ€™ll try to update my Steam review some more (posted May 5, 2020; first edit May 20, 2020 [thanks for all the comments, I've read all of them, they're much appreciated]). Intro: If I were to explain Terraria to someone quickly, I would put it like this: Terraria is a game that has a whole world to explore. You mine, build, craft, fish, and fight to progress through the game. You can focus on fighting enemies and improving your gear to fight various bosses, and/or you can focus on building your house and buildings and making things look pretty. Terraria has something for everyone. The combination of survival, fighting, exploration, and building aspects is satisfying (even though I'm someone who usually plays shooter games). So I believe that you can find something in Terraria for you. Building: When Re-Logic added half blocks and slanted blocks to Terraria in 1.2, the building got so much more interesting and versatile. There are so many different types of blocks in this game with their own unique textures and styles, and with paint there are even more possibilities. Some of the creations made in this game are insanely good. Difficulty: Overall, Terraria on Softcore and Normal mode is not that hard, but just be aware that no matter what, youâ€™ll probably die a lot as a beginner. If you like a challenge, however, Expert mode is the way to go (plus you get extra advantages, such as exclusive accessories, for having an increased difficulty). Even more difficult is Master mode, giving you even more loot than Expert mode. And if you want the game to be especially difficult, you could choose Mediumcore (drop all items on death), or Hardcore (permadeath). Personally, I think Softcore and Expert mode is the most fun way to play. Music: Terrariaâ€™s music is great. All of it fits with the style of the game. Almost every biome has a unique song to fit with the theme, and there are different songs for bosses and events as well. I bought the official soundtrack and I love to listen to it whenever I want some background music. Multiplayer: Multiplayer is incredibly easy to set up. The easiest way to play is to join/host through Steam. You can also enter an IP address, which, before 1.3, used to be the only way to play multiplayer at all, but now it's so much easier with Steam integration. Connection is rarely a problem for me, although I think Iâ€™ve found that the host has worse lag than the other players, when there is lag that is. Terraria is very fun to play with friends and even just with strangers. There are teaming options, PVP, and other multiplayer elements built into the game. Bosses are often much easier to beat on multiplayer as well, because usually if one player dies, the other player can continue to fight the boss and stay alive long enough to let the first player respawn. Performance: Terraria runs very well. On my custom PC, which is great for gaming, the game runs perfectly on max settings and has nearly instantaneous loading speeds. On my HP computer, which is not built for gaming, and on my 11-year-old Toshiba laptop, the game runs very nicely on low settings, with only minor loading times. There are several video settings that can be modified to help performance. I would recommend at least turning the background and effects off for lower-end computers. Price: Terraria is very inexpensive. Itâ€™s one of the few games Iâ€™ve bought at full price and found it completely worth it. Struggles: Terraria has a learning curve. There are many things left up to you to figure out from the start. The Guide NPC is there to give some help. Many things, however, are left up to the player to figure out, much of which is just learned through time and experience. I would recommend looking up tips, tricks, and other information online, such as on the Official Terraria Wiki, or watch videos, like those of ChippyGaming and Edward on YouTube. Personally, I enjoy the learning curve, and the struggle to learn new things is just the right amount to be enjoyable and not annoying. To get to the endgame of Terraria, it does take a while. There is so much content and so many bosses in just vanilla Terraria, that it can be overwhelming, and progression can sometimes feel slow. You may want to rush things like bosses, but you have to prepare well for bosses, or else youâ€™ll probably die. Once you defeat bosses, however, it feels so worth it. And you donâ€™t have to follow an exactly linear path either. Also, you donâ€™t have to play for 30+ hours for a full playthrough just to feel accomplished. From 1 to 10000 hours, this game is fun for any length of time. My biggest struggle with this game is the grind for certain items. Some items are extremely hard to get, due to low drop rates or pretty extreme circumstances. There are many, many items with a drop chance lower than 1%. Realistically, you wonâ€™t get every item in the game, if thatâ€™s what youâ€™re aiming for. I once wanted to get every enemy banner in the game (you have to kill 50 of the same enemy to get a banner) legitimately, but I gave up on that idea because of how grindy it is to kill 50 of each enemy for the rarest ones (that darn Nymph Banner). To put it simply, itâ€™s possible to get every item in the game, but itâ€™s just not worth it. You should, however, build farms for certain items. But the point is, just get the items in the game that you really want to get legitimately, and itâ€™ll be worth it (if you did want every single item in the game, you can use inventory editors or go to free item servers, but itâ€™s not fun to abuse these). Tips: * Organize and name chests ASAP * Place rope down a Hellevator * Use Cursed/Ichor Torches (craftable in Hardmode) for Hellevators and bridges, since theyâ€™re liquidproof * Use the Hardy Saddle (Turtle Mount) with Brick Layer/Architect Gizmo Pack to place down blocks in a straight line at a constant speed, which is perfect for building bridges * Look up how to maintain world purity, since the Corruption, Crimson, and the Hallow biomes spread across the world, and the Corruption/Crimson can destroy the Jungle biome over time and do other unfortunate things * Go fishing. Itâ€™s worth it. As of 1.4, saving crates from pre-Hardmode to open in Hardmode no longer has the chance of giving you Hardmode ores. But fishing is still very much worth it for the large number of tools, accessories, and other loot you can get * Use Logic Sensors (Player Above) and Actuators for enemy/NPC-proof doors * Use Invisibility Potions while farming for Truffle Worms * Use Warmth Potions for the Frost Moon Conclusion: I've played this game for over 8 years now. I made a Steam account for this game, and I've played through so much of the game's development back when there wasn't even a fraction of the number of items in the game. To put it simply, Terraria is my favorite game. So after over a 1000 hours of playtime, I can safely say that I 100% recommend buying and playing Terraria. i made this :)", "appid": "105600", "steamid": "profiles/76561198052866704", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1590494400.0}

{"text": "The Piranha's finest and maybe their best title. Despite a rather small size of the island, every location brims with love and effort spent into creating it. The world feels complete, no unnecessary detail, no location out of place. The combat is engaging and the progression keeps this going well into the endgame, where you might get tired a bit from the final enemy types, particularly if you want all experience. Why a thumbs down, then? The game is abandoned and unoptimized for newer versions of OS. This becomes particularly evident on the second playthrough, when you can run out of memory. The only way to fix it is to patch the executable with a program, which will bring it's virtual memory use potential up to 4 GB, in line with 64-bit systems. And guess what, you can't do that with a Steam Risen executable. People on the forums tried to contact the devs/publishers about the issue without success. There are still some very annoying issues in the game, that could be easily addressed by the devs, but never were. I highly suggest you get the unofficial patch from the World of Risen website. A lot of users on the forums report being unable to start the game due to gfx-related problem. I had it too, I think you manually have to change the resolution in the ini file to match your monitor's to make it work, but I'm not completely sure. No support, no Steam cloud, existing in-game achievements never mirrored. You get the picture. So, would I recommend you play Risen, especially if you're Gothic fan - oh God, yes, absolutely. There is no need to get Steam version for that, though.", "appid": "40300", "steamid": "profiles/76561198065011346", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "187", "votes_funny": "8", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1465646400.0}

{"text": "This game reminds me of a comment Jonathen Blow made about AAA games these days evoking feeling of bad action movies. I said it, and I feel that's just what Tomb Raider is. At the beginning of the game I was hooked into the setting. The graphics were beautiful, the controls responsive the sound design well done... it had all the potential in the world. This is still a game I'd personally recommend as something to play to other people, but I'd wait for a bargain bin price personally. For me what began as fun, finding all the little collectibles and doing side hunt after side hunt, quickly spiraled into okay I just wanna finish this game. The story was completely uninteresting to me. I could partially blame this on playing Specs Ops: The Line before this. I want to care about characters like that. I cared about no one in Tomb Raider. That and some of the trials and tribulations Lara initially goes through emotionally speaking, I could be speaking out of cynicism here, but I felt they were just there to show her feminism. This saddens me. I hate saying something like that. I also think it's poor of developer to make a choice that, \"this is how a female would act.\" This could be my cynicism again. I just can't help but feel the writing direction was well â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. The character development was â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. Calling action sequence, chase sequence, or exploration sequence before they were happening just show how un-immersed I was. I was watching the game more than actively engaging with it. It was a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ B action movie with a pedigree. Even then Lara never felt like she made a place. You could have swapped out with any \"dude bro\" and the game wouldn't have been any different. When you can swap out your main character I'd think that's a clue that she's under developed. {"text": "or watch it here:  You are searching for your brother who seems to have vanished into thin air. While looking for information, you stumble across an ancient brotherhood that protects a powerful object called the Eye of Basir. I donâ€™t want to give away too many details, but as the story developed, there was the potential for the game to really delve into the supernatural, and psychological horror.  The gameplay feels like that of a walking simulator. The atmosphere may be a little spooky at times, but the gameâ€™s attempts at jump scares fall flat. As you play, you will need to find and interact with objects in order to trigger events. You can only interact with the specific items that are intended for immediate use, and you wind up having to do a lot of backtracking to trigger events before you can progress. On the Steam store page, the game claims to have â€œdifficult puzzles,â€ but frankly, the â€œpuzzlesâ€ are a complete joke. You use an item to view the world a slightly differently, but the majority of the game feels more like a series of fetch quests and item search rather than anything else, and itâ€™s not particularly engaging or enjoyable. {"text": "This is only for the single player, mostly because I don't really care about the multiplayer for this. As far as graphics and production values, you won't go wrong with COD:WWII. It's eye candy all over the place and there's no regrets in that department. Gameplay is where things start to fall apart: I really enjoyed the fact that there's medic pouches that you need to use (instead of hide n' heal used elsewhere). The idea of using your squad mates to get ammo and other \"power-ups\" is really interesting, but sadly it's limited to 4 different kinds of requests. The rest, however, is where this game is the weakest: missions are nothing to write home about. I'm hard-pressed to remember any particular moment that stands out. What sucks the most is that the enemy pretty much zeroes in on killing you, which I guess makes sense because the entire war effort is moved by you because your squad mates can't hit anything. {"text": "Sometimes less is more. This game was better and easier to figure out back when there was far less going on. There's so much visual noise on the board now. One thing that makes these kinds of games good in the Dota Chess genre is that you can see the actions, power, and shortcomings of your individual pieces. I.E. you see that your choices matter. This has now basically been ruined in this game. For context, the recent update has added the Underlords, which are essentially a Hero unit. The problem is these guys (only 2 in the game right now) have like 10+ abilities, and you can't tell when they're triggering or what they're doing in a visibly noticeable way. It adds way more noise to the board, and it's generally just a pointless feature. The game was fine without them, they feel super gimmicky, and it erases some of the cool parts about the game, like having each game and team feel different. Additionally, Underlords have extra abilities only unlocked if you're already doing really well in the game, so that's something else added to snowball early success and prevent come-back victories. Additionally, the recent update has destroyed the existing, simple, readable UI to accomdate the Underlords' extra features and stuff that just the amount of screen the Underlords UI takes up is almost as big as the entirety of the old UI. The whole UI now is very clunky, things moved into very un-instinctive places. I doubt that any of this gets reverted. But the game was better when it was leaner, simpler, and easier to read. While choices you make still matter, it's way harder to see that difference play out. Additionally this recent update added a load of new chess pieces, a couple new alliances, and shuffled/changes almost all the previous ones. I'll give this the benefit of the doubt and say it's okay because if you play long enough you'll learn them, but many feel very unintuitive. While on the surface, adding more chess pieces seems like a good thing, it just ends up clogging up your draws and decreasing the chance you have of getting the specific pieces you want for your composition. If you were already not jazzed about the RNG of whether or not you drew this certain hero to round out your team, just wait til there's 20+ more heroes that you can possibly get on top of the existing ones that will come up instead.", "appid": "1046930", "steamid": "profiles/76561198328031854", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "68", "votes_funny": "6", "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1574856000.0}

Definitely not the flashlight coverage shown in the store screenshots.  In a room with some chairs and a small TV.  The chairs in back light up from all angles, but the ones closest to me do not. Nor is there a ring of light as most dark games with flashlights.  Doors stand out pretty nicely as does blood splatter :D: but you can't see much in the halls to know where you can or can't walk. {"text": "This review was written based off gameplay in patch 0.4.2 Astral Terra is a game that is very much in its infancy. It's probably too early for it to be sold to the public at the minute. I understand that Early Access is for games that are still developing, but I don't feel that this game is ready to demand a price tag at the moment. There's potential here, but a lot of optimisation and work needs to be done. There's a complete lack of tutorial. The game throws you in and expects you to know what you're doing. There is no way to change the key bindings at the moment. Once you have figured things out, everything in the game is a little awkward and clunky. The cursor needs to be placed exactly where the game wants it to be for something to work. This is especially frustrating when it comes to gathering materials and trying to pick them up. Everything must be clicked on individually, and sometimes you need to click outside of the texture of an item to pick it up. It leads to a lot of frustration and makes everything feel very slow and laboured. Even when terraforming, it can be difficult to get the game to do what you want it to do.  The world looks really good for a game in this genre. The environment is vibrant and huge. However, the character models are of considerably lower quality than the rest of the game, they don't fit in. Movement also looks a little unnatural.  Right now the game is essentially a creative environment and nothing more. There's no challenging enemies, just an empty world to explore. It would be acceptable for this to be a creative game if it wasn't so frustrating to play. When it feels like you're fighting the game just to be able to play it, it gets exhausting quickly. Astral Terra is not a bad game, it's just a frustrating experience right now. As the game evolves and is updated, hopefully it will become more intuitive to play and create a better experience for the user. I'll re-visit the game across it's life, and hopefully the potential will be achieved and I can change this review and recommend it. Right now, I can't justify telling anyone they should spend their money on it though.", "appid": "266190", "steamid": "profiles/76561197994239917", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "12", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1463486400.0}

{"text": "A great game, ruined by bad controls. The controls of a breakout game are probably the simplest in ANY game. There is left, there is right, and there is a button to launch the ball. That's it!.. VERY difficult to mess up, but Ironsun Studios managed to do just that. The movement is clumsy and unresponsive. At first I thought there was something wrong with the sensitivity, then I noticed how the bar wouldn't move at all, unless the mouse was moved at a certain speed. The developers put in deadzones!! They seriously put time and effort into making it unresponsive to small movements. If you have ever played a breakout game, you know that small movements are extremely important for being able to hit the ball at the right angle. Aiming goes out the window, and it gets even more frustrating when you loose a life, because the bar just didn't move, even though you actually moved the mouse. The game looks fun and all, but it's a constant frustration that you can't move the bar in a natural fluent way. It's a real shame. The game would have been fun to play, had the control not been massed up. If a fix comes out, please let me know. For now I can't recommend this game. Guild wars are a joke and consists more of pathetic drama than you think. Here's the question: How do the creators expect the weak to become stronger if the strong keep taking from them? {"text": "For formatting and pics go to:  What Space Base DF-9 did right  -Great visual Appeal One of the things i love about SBDF-9 is the look and style, they just seem right. And it reminds me of the Sims 4 or Sim City(2013) -Great idea for a game lots of people have done building games, city games,etc, but Space Bases are few. The idea for this game is Perfect, now if only the game was... What Space Base DF-9 did wrong -Did not deliver on the Double Fine Games website they had a roadmap (now long gone) of things they said they were going to try to add. It was a big one. And yes i know that even they said it wasn't \"set in stone\" but it was used to get people to buy the game, and now only about 20 to 40% of those features are in the game, and it kinda feels like they tricked us.  -Left the Game unfinished Double Fine Games the dev and publisher has left SBDF-9 to make another game and thereby make more money. They basically blame the community citing that \"not enough people bought the game to fund it\". Perhaps because the game is in an Alpha state at the most  -retarded AI I don't know about you but when i'm in a space base on the far reaches of the milky way, i get pretty damn pissed when i don't have Five Star meals, or Gyms, or bars, or TV. So mad i start trashing my own Oxygen tanks thereby killing myself. What? You wouldn't do that? Well the AI in this game does that. Yep, if they aren't living in luxury they decide life just ain't worth living.  -Not Worth the price If Double Fine Games was going to keep working on this, i would say this is worth the price, however they aren't so really there is no point in spending cash on it. Its not going to get better, its not going to get fixed, and its not a good game.  -bugs and glitches that will never be fixed Not being able to build, Oxygen not being produced despite the fact i have Oxygen tanks and more, these are bugs and glitches that will never be fixed.  -Made us pay for their failure This is more of a issue of Double Fine Games itself. They the whole reason they said the game is being shut down is because one: Not enough people bought it, and two: they ran out of Kickstarter money. If they did run out of kickstarter money then STOP working on another game and spend that money on the game you sold us.  -This is not the first time Double Fine Game has let people down Another game by DFG, Broken Age was also misleading. The game is sold as a full game but it is like TellTale games in that there are \"Episodes\". Right now, a year after the funding for the game ended there is only ONE  episode, with a \"promise\" that the second one will be coming on \"sometime in early 2015\"  Who Space Base DF-9 is for -People who like wasting money  -People who don't care about playing an unfinished game  -People who buy games on sale  -Idiots Final Thoughts The idea behind this game is amazing, and if worked on properly it could be a masterpiece. But it won't and thats a shame. Normally i keep supporting even bad EA games because i figure \"eh, they will fix it later\" i mean at the point i've already given them money, the best thing to do is hold on to the hope (however pointless) that the game will get better.
